title: 114_hr2357
content:
The "Accelerating Access to Capital Act of 2016" allows expanded eligibility for the use of Form S-3 by the Securities and Exchange Commission. This revision permits securities to be registered under certain conditions, including a minimum aggregate market value of common equity or listing on a national securities exchange. Additionally, the Act provides exemptions for micro-offerings. The "Accelerating Access to Capital Act of 2016" expands Form S-3 eligibility by the SEC, allowing registration of securities under specific conditions. It also provides exemptions for micro-offerings involving transactions with limited purchasers and pre-existing relationships with issuer stakeholders. The exemption under subsection (a)(8) allows for limited offerings with up to 35 purchasers and a total amount not exceeding $500,000 in a 12-month period. Disqualification applies if any person triggers disqualification under section 230.506(d) of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations. Persons described in 230.506(d) of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations include the issuer, any predecessor or affiliated issuer, directors, officers, general partners, beneficial owners of 20% or more voting equity securities, promoters, investment managers of pooled investment funds, and disqualified persons. The text discusses amendments to the Securities Act of 1933 regarding persons involved in the sale of securities, including those receiving remuneration for solicitation, general partners, managing members, and officers of investment managers or solicitors. Additionally, an exemption under state regulations is added. TITLE III--PRIVATE PLACEMENT IMPROVEMENT

SEC. 301. REVISIONS TO SEC REGULATION D. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise Regulation D within 45 days of the enactment of the Act. The revisions include requiring issuers to file a single notice of sales for each new offering of securities under Rule 506, making Form D filings available to state securities commissions, and not conditioning availability on any requirements. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise Regulation D within 45 days of the enactment of the Act. The revisions include not conditioning the availability of exemptions for issuers under Rule 506 on filing Form D, not requiring written general solicitation materials for Rule 506(c) offerings, not extending Rule 156 requirements to private funds, and revising Rule 501(a) to include "knowledgeable employees" of private funds. The SEC will amend Regulation D to include "knowledgeable employees" of private funds as accredited investors for Rule 506 offerings related to the fund they work for. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 8, 2016. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
